More Notes: Permanent reduction; Long run assumed to be 2100
Damage caused by natural disasters between 2 and 15 percent of an exposed country’s annual GDP (averaged across the period).
Damage caused by natural disasters between 2 and 15 percent of an exposed country’s annual GDP (averaged across the period).

Reduction in output is proportional to reduction in capital stock in the short term. This outcome is from a macroeconomic model constructed by Albala-Bertrand (1993a). This is a negative relationship, but has been converted to a value of -1.

Author modifies some assumptions, considering that loss is split between capital and output, that capital loss is estimated at replacement cost, and that capital is heterogeneous, resulting in a much smaller impact on output from a one-time disaster. This outcome is from a macroeconomic model constructed by Albala-Bertrand (1993a). This is a positive relationship, but has been converted to a value of 1.
Approved by World Bank to cover IDA debt interest over 12 months after the 2000 flood
Yearly economic cost. South Africa spends about US$5 million yearly for the economic cost of natural hazards. IEG 2006 is cited.
